    • Method Detail

      • formatObject

        public static String formatObject(boolean identify,
                                  boolean qualified,
                                  Object object)
        Returns a textual representation of the given object. In particular:
        • if the object is null, returns "null";
        • if the object is a proxy and has custom identity, Proxies.Identity.toString() is invoked with the object and its result is returned;
        • if the object is a proxy, has no custom identity, and identity is false, then "proxy[<list of interfaces>]" is returned;
        • if the object is a proxy, has no custom identity, and identity is true, then Strings.formatId() is invoked and returned;
        • if the object overrides Object.toString(), the result of invoking that method is returned;
        • Otherwise if identity is true then Strings.formatId() is invoked and returned, else the fully qualified name of the object type is returned.

        Arrays are formatted as the list of individual items, surrounded with brackets.

        Parameters:
        identify - tells if object identity is to be formatted in absence of a custom Object.toString() method (true) or just the type identity (false).
        qualified - specifies whether the fully qualified class name of the object should be used (true) or only its name (false).
        object - the object to format; may be null.
        Returns:
        the the proxy friendly textual representation, if any, or the identity of the given object.

      • formatClass

        public static String formatClass(boolean kind,
                                 boolean qualified,
                                 Class<?> type)
        Formats a class name. For arrays, this method adds "[]" to the class name once for each step in the depth of the array. For instance: 
         assert Strings.formatClass(false, false, Object[][][].class).equals("Object[][][]");
 assert Strings.formatClass(false, true, Object[][][].class).equals("java.lang.Object[][][]");
        Parameters:
        kind - if true, the type's string representation is used, otherwise only its name is used.
        qualified - if true, the type's fully qualified name is used, otherwise its simple name is used.
        type - the class, which may be an array.
        Returns:
        the textual representation of the given class.

      • formatId

        public static String formatId(Object object)
        For proxies, it returns "proxy@<identity hash code>[<list of interfaces>]"; for ordinary classes, it returns "<fully qualified class name>@<identity hash code>"; arrays are formatted as described at formatClass(boolean, boolean, Class).

        Arrays are formatted as the list of individual items, surrounded with brackets.

        Parameters:
        object - the object to format; may be null.
        Returns:
        the proxy friendly run-time identity of the given object.

      • describeAnnotation

        public static String describeAnnotation(boolean identity,
                                        Annotation annotation)
        Forms the simple Java-like notation or an identifier of the given annotation instance. Examples of the Java-like notation:
        • @MyAnnotation: "@MyAnnotation"
        • @MyAnnotation(1000): "@MyAnnotation(1000)"
        • @MyAnnotation(id = 1000, code = "abcd"): "@MyAnnotation(id=1000,code=\"abcd\")"
        • @MyAnnotation({ 1, 2, 3 }): "@MyAnnotation({1,2,3})"

        Parameters set to their default value are not included.

        Parameters:
        identity - if true, return an identifier for the annotation, otherwise its Java-like form.
        annotation - the annotation instance to return the Java-like form of.
        Returns:
        the Java-like notation or an identifier for the given annotation.
